sub_title: Director The 21st Century Museum || inclusive institutions where we can see ourselves | curating+consultancy+fundraising
summary:
Janna el Isa works as independent curator and artistic director of The 21st Century Museum. Some of her most recent curatorial projects are NEW SUNS | Kahlil Joseph RE:INTERPRETED at Bonnefantenmuseum and Black Presence at the Sugar Palace at Mauritshuis. 

With her curatorial agency she works on innovation, representation and inclusivity in cultural institutions. She revisits the notions of art, identity and heritage; cultural citizenship, ancestral lineages and collective memory as they are reproduced through our art institutions from a decolonial perspective. Through her work she aims to curate new paradigms and discourses; inclusive institutions, programs and exhibitions in which specifically young local audiences from a diversity of backgrounds can recognise themselves.

As a curator she creates embodied art experiences; bringing together the visual and the sonic, words and movements to create multidimensional art worlds in alignment with our 21st century arts and culture, representing our current times and consciousness. 

She currently works on a series of interventions in major art institutions in which she holds space for diasporic notions of art, culture and hybrid heritage, of which New Fashion Narratives: Diasporic Dutch Identities and Our Pride is Intersectional x Amsterdam Rainbow Dress at Amsterdam Museum are examples. In 2018 she will further develop the Black Presence-series in public art institutions, creating space for and discourse through diasporic perspectives in Dutch contemporary art. 

/ visit for more information about past, present and future projects | jannaelisa.wordpress.com

school.name: HU University of Applied Sciences Utrecht

education.field_of_study: Cultural and Social Development; Specialization Art + Community and Art Education
education.grade: Thesis 'The creative human being and the arts' (9,0)

profile_positions.description:
The Inclusive Institution // co-creating inclusive art worlds

The Inclusive Institution provides cultural institutions consultancy and hands-on experience around inclusivity from a holistic approach of be(com)ing a relevant institution in our 21st century society.

Director and founder Janna el Isa has been working as curator and programmer with a community-based approach with organisations like Mauritshuis, Amsterdam Museum, The Black Archives, Van Abbemuseum and Centraal Museum. Within the field of both visual and performative arts she has a strong connection with local communities through her background in the urban arts and culture scene. Her work as curator is dedicated to create space in institutions for inclusive programs in co-creation with local artists and creatives. This bottom-up approach starts at the experiences of local audiences, creating content in which the global societies, diverse communities and urban realities of the 21st century are represented. Her main focus with programs like Black Presence at the Sugar Palace (Mauritshuis) is to curate inclusive art worlds in public institutions in which people from different backgrounds can recognise themselves.
profile_positions.title: Director & Consultant

profile_positions.description:
The 21st Century Museum is the embodiment of a relevant and inclusive institution representing our current global societies | diverse communities | urban realities.

As a curatorial agency we work on innovation, representation and inclusivity in the cultural world.  Through curating exhibitions and events with a diverse group of artists and critical thinkers we represent plural narratives and multiple perspectives upon the world we live in. This is our way to create art worlds in which a variety of people from a diversity of backgrounds can recognise themselves. 

Our inspiration is the 21st century art and culture that we see being created in our local surroundings - this content that embodies our current times and consciousness is what we bring in cultural institutions to create connections and immersive art experiences with local audiences.

In #takeovers of museums such as the Mauritshuis and Amsterdam Museum we co-created the following programs with our collective of artists, visionairies and communities:

NEW SUNS / KAHLIL JOSEPH RE:INTERPRETED | Bonnefantenmuseum

Black Presence at the Sugar Palace | Mauritshuis

Our Pride is Intersectional | Amsterdam Museum

New Fashion Narratives | Amsterdam Museum 

The 21st Century Museum could be seen as a re-vision of our cultural institutions, the identities and communities, the ‘we’ that our institutions represent. In order to become relevant for twenty-first century audiences from a variety of backgrounds it might be time to update our content and co-create programs with local culture makers, representing different art worlds, cultures, perspectives, experiences and identities in which a diversity of people can recognize themselves.
profile_positions.title: Artistic Director

profile_positions.description:
NEW SUNS | KAHLIL JOSEPH RE:INTERPRETED

In honour of Kahlil Joseph's art and his first solo exhibition in an European museum The 21st Century Museum curated the NEW SUNS finissage at Bonnefantenmuseum (NL). 

Artists from Dutch soil re:interpreted Joseph's art through the elements of music, dance, fashion and spoken word. Their art, presence and performances added inspiring new layers of meaning to Joseph's art and exhibition, while creating an multidimensional art experience through references to Hiphop culture and Afrofuturism in Joseph's impressive body of work.

Curated by Janna el Isa | The 21st Century Museum
Commissioned by Bonnefantenmuseum, The Netherlands
profile_positions.title: Curator | NEW SUNS / KAHLIL JOSEPH RE:INTERPRETED

profile_positions.description:
Black and Revolutionary: The Story of Hermina and Otto Huiswoud

… a hidden history of two black revolutionaries and their adventurous struggle against colonialism, racism and economic inequality.

Black emancipation in the Netherlands
The life of the Huiswoud connected them to an international network of anti-colonial thinkers, writers and activists, such as Anton de Kom, Marcus Garvey, W.E.B. Du Bois and Langston Hughes. The story of the Huiswouds shows that there has been a long tradition of black emancipation and political organizing in the Netherlands. Due to the involvement of the Huiswouds, Vereniging Ons Suriname became a hub for a political movement striving for the independence of Suriname as well as against racial discrimination and inequality in the Netherlands.

Discover hidden history!
The Black Archives uncovers this long-hidden story in an exhibit that features unique documents from the personal archives of Hermina and Otto Huiswoud and artworks by Iris Kensmil, Brian Elstak and Raul Balai. Visitors are invited to come explore this hidden history together with The Black Archives.
profile_positions.title: Co-curator contemporary art | Black & Revolutionary

profile_positions.description:
Black Presence at the Sugar Palace

#takeover of the Mauritshuis curated by Janna el Isa​ | The 21st Century Museum in co-creation with our collective of artists and visionaries.

“... taking over the Sugar Palace that was built by the ancestors. In these spaces we write our pasts, presents and futures in stories, visuals, spoken word, dance and hiphop beats - honouring the ancestors, the contemporaries and future generations. Honouring the Black Presence at the Sugar Palace from back then, right now and in the futures to come.”
profile_positions.title: Curator | Black Presence at the Sugar Palace

profile_positions.description:
Curating an inclusive and decolonial fashion history that focuses upon diasporic fashion identities in the Netherlands

New Fashion Narratives Pt. 1. | Diasporic Dutch Identities in 21st Century Fashion

Collaboration between Amsterdam Museum and Modemuze
profile_positions.title: Curator | New Fashion Narratives

profile_positions.description:
Our Pride Is Intersectional

Curating the transfer ceremony of the Amsterdam Rainbow Dress centred around a Vogueing performance by dancers of the House of Vineyard. The  ballroom culture and Vogue dancing came into existence in the marginalised Black LGBTI-communities in New York in the 1980s. The communities form together a house that is a safe spaces of expression, empowerment and celebration of diverse identities 

In collaboration with the Amsterdam City Council and Amsterdam Museum
profile_positions.title: Curator | Pride 2017 x Amsterdam Rainbow Dress

profile_positions.description: Researching and writing a history of eighty years Van Abbemuseum. We perceive the museum as a museum in motion, an open entity, an ongoing open-ended project of fluxing histories and identities. This history of the past and the present is written and researched from our contemporary position, not in a one-dimensial but rather in a caleidoscopic way from four different point of views: Collecting & Sharing, Exhibiting & Curating, Mediating & Using, Building & Constructing.
profile_positions.title: Researcher | Museum Book - Collecting, Exhibiting and Mediating In the Van Abbemuseum 1936 - 2016

profile_positions.description:
Through several waves of migration the twenty-first century Dutch society has developed into a transcultural society. A growing number of artists embodies this reality and develops a transnational Dutch art history, relating Dutch and European histories to transcontinental movements and art histories. With their bodies of work artists are challenging the modernist notions of the museum, the art historical canon and their implications of 'universality' - radically transcending these set-up borders, creating worlds in which a variety of worlds co-exist. 

From their positition in a transcultural Dutch society these artists provide useful contemporary perspectives on what it means to live in our twenty-first century globalised world, however, their work has remained relatively invisible and absent in Dutch art museums. This research aims to 'canonise', historicize and re-member these artistic bodies of knowledge that reflect our twenty-first century contemporaneity, while at the same time examining the museum as national 'keeper of memories' and how this institution relates to current notions of transnationality and transculturality. Furthermore, this research aims to create a productive curatorial and art-historical approach that displaces migratory aesthetics and diasporic subjectivities from the margins to the centre, as a response to our contemporary societal condition - 'seeking a now that can breed futures' (Audre Lorde).
profile_positions.title: Worlds Beyond the Visible and Knowable-Double Consciousness and the Global in Dutch Contemporary Art

profile_positions.description:
'El Lissitzky: The Artist And the State' introduces the artistic practice of Lissitzky for the first time in history in Ireland. The exhibition included Lissitzky's artworks from the Van Abbe collection, juxtaposed with his contemporaries Alice Milligan and Maud Gonne, two Irish artists-activists who used their artistic practice to imagine the Irish state in the early twentieth century. All of these artists perceived their role as artist as being an active participant in the formation of the new world order.  The exhibition reflected upon the position of artists in civil society who envisage their creative practices as tools for social and political change. A contemporary narrative was provided through the work of Rossella Biscotti, Núria Güell, Sarah Pierce and Hito Steyerl, artists who are all working with the concept of 'the state' as well. 

Another important part of the exhibition were the archival material and books about Lissitzky, made accesible for visitors in the Reading Room. The books in this room gave visitors access to Lissitzky's ideas, encouraging them to actively use the material to dive in his ideas, enabling people to gain useful knowledge and draw inspiration from the material.
profile_positions.title: El Lissitzky: The Artist And the State (Irish Museum of Modern Art in Dublin, 2015)

profile_positions.description:
The non-purchasing process of Sanja Ivekovic' Triangle (Trokut, 1979) unraveled.

profile_positions.title: Curator | The Uncollected Collection / Curating the Archive

profile_positions.description:
Positions #2 (november 2015)

'A Personal View On "the History"'

Participating artists:
Anna Boghiguian
Chia-Wei Hsu
Nástio Mosquito
Sarah Pierce

Positions #2 brings together a series of new and older works developed by artists from all around the world. The exhibition has the subject of different histories at its core. History is told from different places, different times and in different forms. This personal view is deployed in a variety of media: paintings, installations, performances and videos.
profile_positions.title: Assistant Curator | Positions #2

profile_positions.description: Curated insert in Ahmet Ögüt's solo exhibition 'Forward!' in solidarity and support of the student protests for democracy and transparency at the University of Amsterdam.
profile_positions.title: Curator | Strijd - Student Protests at the Maagdenhuis 1969 - 2015

profile_positions.description: This exhibition proposal draw attention to the oftenly forgotten past of the Dutch colonisation of the former 'Dutch Indies' (contemporary Indonesia). Because of the Dutch colonisation this part of the world belonged to the Netherlands for centuries, nevertheless does its history nowadays not really seem to belong to the Dutch national historical canon. The proposal took one photograph from the Tropenmuseum collection as starting point to let the depicted people tell their multitudes of histories, entangling topics of postcolonialism and decolonisation, feminism and body politics, objectification and subjectivities, shared identities and micro histories.
profile_positions.title: Their Story is Our Story: The (Un)usual Past
